I think that it was the 8th bus stop from Anguk. Continue to walk uphill for 5 minutes and the Seoul Fortress wall will be seen. Walk along the path next to the wall for 600 meters, always keeping the wall in view on your left, and you will reach Malbawi information Center. It should be noted that there are few signs in English , and at one point a small foot bridge is passed and a really steep staircase that when climbed takes you over the wall. When on the other side of the wall, the malbawi Information center is a 5 minute walk away.Passports have to be provided for inspection and a form filled out, after which an ID tag will be received. This tag is placed around your neck and will have to be returned to Changuimun/Malbawi Information Center after your hike is completed. Guards are posted at regular intervals along the trail, and photos may only be taken at the following areas: Sukjeongmun gate, Baegakmaru, Chatdaebawi Rock, 1.21 Pine Tree, Baegak Rest area and Dolrae Rest Area. If in doubt, ask the guard if you can take a photo.The hike offers beautiful views of Seoul, and the North and Northwest gates of Seoul Fortress. At the Changuimun Gate there is a bronze statue and memorial stone for soldiers who died during the 1.21 incident. Buses to Gwanghwamun Square can be easily taken by crossing the road at Changuimun gate.My wife, 5 year old son and I did this hike from Hyehwamun Gate to Changuimun Gate over a duration of about 4 hours. My son is very active, a strong hiker, and had no problem with the physical challenge. My wife and I are fit but nevertheless our legs were quite sore by the end of the hike. From the direction we came (East to West) there is a very steep 300m decsent at the end of the hike which was difficult on the knees. The views of Seoul are fantastic. The view looking down on the royal palace is interesting. This hike was not available to civilians until it was opened in 2012. This is a military zone due to the proximity to the Korean presidential residence and photos are restricted. Bring your passport (visitors) or alien registration card (residents) if you are not a Korean citizen.In the area of hyehwa, it's supposedly known for buskers and street performers. While finding a park, my friend and i chanced upon this uphill battle and realized it was a hill. It's not high, but has a great view of Seoul city. The remnants of the fortress allows you to take nice pictures too. However, sunset does not look too good on the hill..If you want, you can walk towards Sindang. You'll come across the mural village that was featured in Running Man (the one where they kicked their shoes up the stairs).It is a far walk though.Here's an idea for a morning commune with nature with some sightseeing of the ancient city wall and vistas to boot. Take a taxi to the entrance of Samcheong Park off of Bukchon-ro. Walk about half an hour uphill following the signs to Malbawi Lookout. At the information desk you will be asked to complete a little form and show your passport and you will be given a visitor tag attached to a lanyard to wear. Pick up an English language map if you wish. Now get ready for an hour of good fun with stairclimbing (at the fastest pace with only one quick camera stop) going up to reach Mt. Bukason and then down to Changuimun Gate where you will return the tag, walk down a flight of stairs and take a taxi home. Of course, this is not only one way to do the hike of the northern wall and you can feel free to hike part or the full way and return to your starting point. The strategic importance of the commanding heights cause the ROK army to be on trail maintenance duty so the developed trail is about as pristine as I have ever seen. The July Pine Tree with bullet holes (North Korean assassin squad had it taken to them in spades!) is curious. DO NOT FORGET YOUR PASSPORT AND WATER BOTTLE!I took the Waryong Park to Changuimun course, and the amount of stairs are no joke. I consider myself fairly fit but I was huffing away at some sections of stairs. The course was not very clearly marked and I had to ask the guards stationed all around to make sure I was going the right way. The scenery made up for it, you could see right across Bugaksan Mountain on a clear day. Remember to bring your passport as registration is a must, and bring plenty of water and some snacks or energy bar. I will hike this trail again when I go to Seoul next time.If you have a little more time on your hands, you can also start from Hyehwa subway station. The walk from the subway station to Sungkyunkwan University is through a nice shopping/cafe area, where you can grab some coffee, lunch or fruit juice. The university has a small entrance in the wall from the street that runs along its west side (Sungkyunkwan-ro 5-gil), head for the old buildings and check out the lecture hall and the ages old gingko tree. Then take the back gate to Waryong park (look up this location on your smartphone). From there, everything is well signed: follow the signs to Malbawi to get to the start of the military area. From there, you can only go one way: the westward one, which is, as others pointed out, the right way to do this hike, as it ends with the endless staircase downwards.On the other hand, the Hyehwa quarter is also a great place to end your day in one of its many bars and restaurants!

Name: 중앙고등학교 (겨울연가 촬영지)
Review: 冬のソナタは全然<U+89B3>ていないに等しいですが、ここが名門の中央高校かと感慨に浸りました。とても立派な校<U+820E>で、高校とはとても思えない造りです。水曜の午後は入場可です。北村のついでに立ち寄った冬ソナのロケ地授業のある時間<U+5E2F>だったからか、門も閉まっていたので外で記念撮影だけしました。となりの韓流グッズ屋さんのおばさんが、シャッタ<U+30FC>をおしてくれました(*^▽^*)安<U+56FD>から1番のマウルバスに<U+4E57>り、急な坂を上り初めてのマウルバス<U+4E57>車と北村散策。坂がきつい道が<U+7D9A>きますが、中央高校が見えた時は<U+61D0>かしかったてます。現在は<U+89B3>光客もまばらで、<U+9759>かです。高校隣の韓流スタ<U+30FC>のグッズのお店はありました。冬のソナタは、１０年以上前に<U+89B3>たことがあり、一度冬のソナタのロケ地ということで見に行きました。ちょうど土曜日で、守衛さんからもＯＫを頂き、敷地<U+5185>に入ることができました。非常に綺麗な校<U+820E>で、<U+6B74>史を感じさせてくれます。地下<U+9244>の安<U+56FD><U+99C5>から<U+6B69>いて、１０分<U+5F37>ですが、途中韓屋もあり、散策にもお<U+52E7>めです。北村散策の時に寄りました。3度目ですが、前２回は校門の外からのぞいただけでした。今回は秋夕だったので<U+5B66>校が休みで、敷地<U+5185>に入ることができました。とても<U+5E83>く、建物が立派です。冬のソナタからだいぶたちましたが、ドラマの場面がよみがえりました。散策中、たまたま近くのお土産屋さんのおじさんがここを<U+6559>えてくれました。冬ソナのロケ地<U+30FB><U+5B9F>際は男子校<U+30FB>おぼっちゃま進<U+5B66>校<U+30FB>週末は見<U+5B66>可<U+30FB>と片言の英語で充分な情報を<U+6559>えて貰いました。おじさん感謝！冬ソナも<U+6C17>になりますが、韓<U+56FD>の高校がどんな感じが興味を持ち、行ってみました。坂を上がるとゴシック式の石造建築の建物が現れ、大<U+5909>趣がありました。時間がなくすぐ出てしまいましたが、<U+89B3>光地ではない（ここは<U+89B3>光地化されているけど）韓<U+56FD>の高校を<U+8997>けてラッキ<U+30FC>でした。訪問月2015年10月ガイドブック<U+63B2>載されている北村に行きたかったのですが、たまたま着いたのがソウル中央高校でした。すごく<U+5E83>くて、校<U+820E>の外まで行きたかったのですが、入っていいのかわからず高校だけ<U+5199><U+771F>撮りました。また住宅街の中にある<U+5B66>校ではなので、行きの日は<U+6B69>くの大<U+5909>だろうなっと思いました。よく見てたドラマだったので、行けて嬉しかったです！ドラマも見ていたし、だいたいの場所も知っていましたが、行ったことはありませんでした。鍾路3街<U+99C5>から北村へ行く途中、雲ヒョン宮に立ち寄って遊んでいたら、道を間違えて桂洞へ迷い混んでしまいました。その桂洞の坂を登った突き<U+5F53>たりにありました。桂洞自<U+4F53>も韓屋の面影が<U+6B8B>っている素敵な街です。ただ、一般の<U+5B66>校なのに<U+89B3>光地化しすぎていて(外<U+56FD>人を見れば「<U+5199><U+771F>撮ってあげようとするおばちゃんなど)少し違和感を感じました。自分も行っておいてナンですが、<U+9759>かにしておいてあげたいなぁ、と。。日本でもブ<U+30FC>ムとなった冬のソナタの撮影に使われた高校です。今ではロケ地として<U+89B3>光にくる人はほとんどいないかな。でもお土産店はまだありました。ロケ地としてではなく、高校の建物も十分立派でキレイな建物てした。冬のソナタのブ<U+30FC>ムから１５年くらいたっているのにいまだに人が集まってくる場所です。ただ、今は日本人はほとんどいなくて中<U+56FD>語が響いています。１００年前の古い校<U+820E>がオシャレですね。見<U+5B66>は校<U+820E><U+5185>には入れませんが、敷地<U+5185>なら土日は自由です。

Name: 북촌 한옥마을
Review: 한옥들이 몰려있는 한옥마을. 하지만 늘 사람들이 몰려있어서 구경하는데는 어려움이 있는 편입니다. 복잡해요..그래도 분위기는 좋네요북촌 한옥마을도 서울을 방문하는 여행객들이 가는 명소 중 하나이다. 정말 전통적인 한옥을 체험할 수 있고 구경할 수 있고 멋진 사진도 찍을 수 있어서 인기가 좋다.골목골목 한옥으로 잘 꾸려진 동네입니다.곳곳에 사진찍을 이쁜 곳 많으니 히한복대여해서 입고 꼭 들리세요.안국역 2번 출구에서 걷거나 마을버스를 타고 어둠속의 대화를 지나서 왼쪽으로 주택가를 들어가는 길을 따라가면 한옥마을 가는 작은 입구를 찾을 수있어요외국인들이 가장 한국적인 곳이 어디냐고 물으면 많은 사람들이 북촌을 뽑는다고 하는데, 기대를 많이해서 그런지 조금의 아쉬움은 있었고, 결국 경제논리에 이곳도 옛모습을 조금씩 잃어버리고 있는 것 같아 아쉬웠음.가장 한국적인 풍경을 볼 수 있는 곳이라서 서울여행하는 분께는 한번쯤 추천합니다. 북에는 볼거리도 많지만 맛있는 음식점도 많아요.아름다운 한국의 전통을 느끼려면 꼭가야하는곳!!!! 매일매일 가도 질리지않는 이곳은 정녕 한국이 맞을까하는 의심도 든다 나만의 여행의 한획을 긋는구나현재 사람들이 거주하고 있으니, 조용히 해달라는대도 시끄러운곳. 배려가 많이 필요한곳으로 보여 씁쓸했습니다. 지도보고도 못찾을뻔 했는데. 안내 해주시는 분이 길목 마다 많이 계셔서 다행히 물어물어 갔습니다. 단촐하나 뷰가 정말 이쁩니다.오르막 길을 걸어 올라가기에 힘들긴 하지만, 한국의 아름다운 한옥과 현대의 고층빌딩을 한눈에 볼 수 있는 매력적인 곳입니다.그러나 실제로 사람들이 거주하는 생활공간이니 시끄럽게 하면 안돼요~사람이 많은 때는 많지만 구석구석 돌아다니는 재미가 있어요.정말 사람이 사는 곳도 있으니(요즘엔 게하가 더 많은 거 같기도하지만..) 너무 시끄럽지 않게 돌아다니는 게 예의입니다.낮과 밤의 매력이 넘치는 곳사진 담기에 딱 좋은 곳하지만 실제로 사람들이 사는 곳이니 조심합시다.기분 좋은 곳.너무 예쁜 곳.계속 가고 싶은 곳

Name: 마로니에 공원
Review: 大<U+5B66>路の中心です。周<U+56F2>には重<U+93AE>スポットが林立です。紅葉が一番きれいですが、新<U+7DD1>後も乙です。イベントも多く、にぎやかでした。<U+6075>化<U+99C5>の直ぐ地近くの公演でゆったりとした雰<U+56F2><U+6C17>が<U+6C17>に入りました。<U+5B66>生さんの姿が目立ちます。明洞とはまた違った良さが味わえます。よく　マロニエ公園　と　名前は聞いていて　一度行ってみたいと思っていたら、なんと何度も通った　地下<U+9244><U+6075>化<U+99C5>から駱山公園や壁<U+753B>村へ行くときに通っていくところでした。申し<U+8A33>ないけれど　特に期待するほどではないと感じました。きっと秋のちょうど綺麗な時なら素敵なのかもしれません。周<U+8FBA>は大<U+5B66>路など　落ち着いているエリアだと思います。ミュ<U+30FC>ジカルを見に大<U+5B66>路に行き、時間があったのでマロニエ公園をうろうろしました。公園<U+5185>では色<U+3005>なパフォ<U+30FC>マンスをしていて、若者が集まっていました。露店で何か買って食べながら過ごすのもよいと思います。地下<U+9244><U+6075>化<U+99C5>を出てすぐ目の前にある公園です。何度か訪れていますが、いつも若い人たちであふれています。演劇の街というだけあって、公演のチラシ配りをしていたり、<U+89B3>劇の<U+52E7>誘をしていたり、吉祥寺の<U+69D8>な雰<U+56F2><U+6C17>を感じました。公園も周<U+56F2>には<U+98F2>食店も多くありました。大<U+5B66>路にある公園です。もともとソウル大<U+5B66>があった場所のようで、模型が展示されていました。美術館などがあって<U+5B66>生だけでなく市民の皆さんが集まって<U+697D>しんでいました。<U+6075>化<U+99C5>の南東にある公園です。　公園、というよりはイベントスペ<U+30FC>スのようになっています。　待ち合わせにもよく使われたり。　<U+5B66>生の街、しかも演劇の盛んな街らしく、舞台のチラシを配っている<U+5B66>生がいたり、いつも活<U+6C17>があります。今回は5月でしたが、ここはやはり秋が最高。　特に人<U+6C17>の少ない早朝が良いです。マロニエ公園は大<U+5B66>路にある公園です。1975年、大<U+5B66>路にあったソウル大<U+5B66>校が移<U+8EE2>した後作られた公園だそうです。休日となれば<U+69D8><U+3005>な芸術イベントが行なわれているここマロニエ公園。展示<U+4F1A>やパフォ<U+30FC>マンス、ライブなどが行なわれます。その時によって違うので、わくわくしますね。しかも無料なので、韓<U+56FD>の芸術や美術に興味がある方も、そうでない方も安心して<U+697D>しめます。マロニエ公園には屋台なんかも出ていて、なんとなく<U+61D0>かしい雰<U+56F2><U+6C17>。休日はここで憩うソウル市民でいっぱいです。

Name: 낙산공원
Review: For a young country like South Korea, this park has changed a lot. The best way to learn about the history and changes in the park and the wall surrounding the park book a free walking tour. This one is called "Seoul fortress" and takes about 2 hours. You will learn about Korean history, the 4 main gates, visit the wall museum and walk up to the top of the park to get a good view of Seoul. It takes 2 to 3 hours because you have to get to the Dongdaemun Station to meet the guide.From Hyehwa Station, I first visited the nearby Marronnier Park before arriving at Naksan park and then continue my way to Ihwa mural village. Reaching the park requires a moderate hike uphill for about 450 meters. It was hot & sunny as I was there around noon. There were only a few locals using the park.The park features multiple facilities an exhibition hall, a pavilion, a center for seniors, basketball courts, badminton courts, and many squares that offer wonderful views of the area below. A portion of the old fortress wall runs through the park. From Naksan Park, visitors can walk along the Seoul City Wall to Dongdaemun.It's a nice park with great views on the city. It's very steep. It's next to Ihwa Maeul so it is easy to combine the two.Close to mural village and good leisurely place to hike. The view at the top is amazing and can see Seoul N tower from far away. The sakura there was unbelievable and relatively less crowded, so you can actually have a picnic and enjoy the view from the top. Can also hike from Naksan park down along the way to DongDaeMun in around an hour if taking your time to take in everything. Would definitely recommend, even those with children.beautiful view in the cherry blossom season, fresh air for comfortable walk up the hill .Another suggested season to visit would be October to November. A refresh spot located in the city Centre. One of the four mountains in Seoul city.Although not many, I think the cherry blossom here completes the park and makes it a beautiful place to walk and spend time with love ones.Do visit the mural village which is just a 10 mins walk away, worth the visit :)Most of foreign tourist is really familiar with Namsan Park with its cable car and beautiful Seoul's view from the mountain. But, for domestic, there is one similar spot near Dongdaemun, it called Naksan Park. There is China's Great Wall miniatur and you can stroll along this wall to get the peak. The other way, after arriving at dongmyo station exit 10, you can take local green bus no.3 to Naksan Park directly, more efficient for family trip... :)Naksan Park - In Korean ‘nakta’ means camel and ‘san’ means mountain and therefore its camel hump-like appearance. Reaching the park requires a moderate hike uphill from Hyehwa Station in Daehangno for about 450 meters. Located in the center of the Seoul, this historical and beautiful park has panoramic views of the entire city. A portion of the old Seoul Fortress Wall runs (Seoul Seonggwak) built during the Joseon Dynasty for protection against invaders and enemies runs through the park. The serene ambience is a perfect gateway from the city bustle. Its scenic beauty makes it a popular filming location for many Hallyu dramas. Take in the sunset views or stay till evening for twinkling lights of Seoul at Naksan Park. If you head to the eastern side (as you look at the mountain) follow the wall downwards to reach the top of Ihwa Mural Village. Alternatively, hike the downhill stretch to Dongdaemun Gate. If you're deadbeat after the walk, just take bus no. 3 at the top of the park to get off at Dongdaemun station. Directions: Take Subway Line 4 to Hyehwa (Exit 2). Walk 70 meters and make the first left where there is the sculpture for Marronnier Park. Continue on Daehak-ro 8ga-gil for 180 meters until it dead ends and make a right. Continue for 50 meters and make at the second left on to Guldari-gil. Continue uphill for 200 meters to reach the park on the left.Famous place from all the K-Drama. We visited it while walking in the Ihwa Mural Village. We didn't pick the Naksan Park path, instead we climb the Ihwa Mural Village until we find the famous wall where all the K-Drama happening. It's nice and we'll probably hike the Naksan Park if it's not rainingWe were there mid September and the temperature was around 25°C but the wind was cooling. We started our walk from the Seoul City Wall Museum, which is minutes walk from Dongdaemun Station, Exit 9. From there, we walked along a section of the remaining city walls. There are steps along the walls, though some parts have uneven steps. After about 20 minutes into the walk, we reached Ihwa Mural Village where we 'pit stop' to walk around the village to enjoy the numerous murals and arts scattered in the village.From there we continued our walk towards Naksan Park. It was a pleasant walk and from the crowd mix, it can be seen that this park is one of the favourites among locals to enjoy the sunset. We reached the peak just in time for sunset and stayed until the sun has set, when the lights on buildings began to light up this beautiful city.We descended the hill by walking along the city walls and reached our starting point, near Dongdaemun Station, Exit 9.Overall, it was a nice and pleasant walk. Would recommend visiting the park for the sunset at the peak.

Name: 광화문
Review: Well, since it is considered an attraction all by itself and it is right next to Gyeongdukgung Palace, there really isn't any reason to miss Gwanghwamun Gate.Visit when the guards are changing, grab some pictures and move on.This is an impressive and large gate into the palace and best seen during the changing of the guard every hour between 10 AM and 3 PM each day.It was built in 1395 but destroyed during a Japanese invasion in 1592, and rebuilt in 1867. A popular place for tourists.One of the many traditional and historical gates of the city that welcomes you to the past while standing in the middle of the modern technology of the presentThis traditional Korean palace gate, with a distant-mountain backdrop, remained our objective as we ambled North on Gwanghwamun Square. We had come to see Gyeongbokgung Palace, the most important during the Joseon Dynasty, and this main and largest gate to the complex was how we planned to enter. Though the original structure went up in 1395, the gate has endured poor condition, destruction and movement to nearby locations throughout the centuries. The most recent restoration, completed in 2010, is authentic in capturing the original’s look, materials and placement The two-story granite-and-wood pavilion displays a stark-white base, which matches the palace’s outer wall, and a double green-tiled roof. Three archways in the gate reflect how the palace was once entered. The king passed through the central opening, while the crown prince and royal officers used the other two. This beautiful gate, displaying a much earlier-era architecture. seemed strangely juxtapositioned in modern Seoul with nearby tall buildings and much vehicular traffic passing by. A massive courtyard sprawls behind the gate, where visitors can enter for free. An admission charge is assessed, however, to proceed beyond this area. We arrived too late to see the colorful changing of the guard ceremony, which occurs here at 10 a.m. and 2 p.m., but had already witnessed this spectacle elsewhere in the city. Dozens of the myriad visitors standing around wore traditional Korean garments. These can be rented in the courtyard area.For those without time to explore the huge royal palace complex, I recommend a quick stop here to see the gate and timed for the changing of the guards, which does not take place on Tuesdays. There are nearby Metro stops.The gates of the palace, good for photos and specially if you can catch the guards ceremony and changing hours. Check the schedule before coming.The Gwanghwamun Gate is on of the most popular gates in Seoul. All of the gates have an own and unique story which you can figure out.It's just a gate as part of the larger Gyeongbokgung Palace. It's an impressive structure to behold.This is the main gate into the grand palace. While most of these gates look similar, this main gate is impressive. It prepares you to expect the greatness inside.Gwanghwamun is the main gate for the royal palace. Changing of the guard occurs here. A fine piece of Korean architecture.I was very impressed by this massive, ceremonial entrance to Gyeongbokgung Palace. When I first arrived I thought there was a row of mannequins dressed as imperial guards, but they are real! They stands so still, honestly it's quite remarkable. The gate is beautiful when seen from both sides. It is possible to see it for free as the ticket booth is well inside the gate.The changing of the guard ceremony is quite something else but even if you are not there for that, it's a magnificent gate and well worth a lingering stop on my opinion

Name: 문묘
Location: 서울 종로구 성균관로 31 성균관대학교 내에 위치 (우) 110-523
Review: 韓<U+56FD>初の<U+6559>育機<U+95A2>です。一番印象的だったのは、中央にそびえるイチョウの大木。孔子のオフィスにはイチョウの木が植わっていたという故事に法ったもので、６００年<U+7D4C>っていると思われる大木に<U+5727>倒されました。大<U+5B66>路に銀杏が多いことの理由を知れました。成均館大<U+5B66>の敷地<U+5185>にある、朝鮮時代の役人になるための<U+5B66>校、成均館です。<U+6B74>史ドラマなんかでもちょくちょく出てくるのですが、ドラマの雰<U+56F2><U+6C17>とは違いました。入口は非常にわかりにくいです。大<U+5B66>の入口に大きな<U+6B74>史的建物を思わす門があるのですが、ここは閉まっています。ぐるっと回って、小さな入口から入ります。入ってみると、少しだけ雰<U+56F2><U+6C17>が<U+5909>わるので面白いですよ。時間があればよってみてください。周<U+8FBA>は<U+98F2>食店がたくさんあり、大<U+5B66>の近くということもあって比較的安いと思います。昌慶宮の北側にある成均館大<U+5B66>の敷地<U+5185>に復元されている<U+5B66>問所の遺跡です。儒<U+6559>や科<U+6319>に<U+95A2>連する場所です。ここの中央に生えているイチョウの大木は日本でも見たことがないくらい素晴らしいものでした。成均館大<U+5B66>の租として知られる文廟は、大成殿や明倫堂など、見<U+5FDC>えがある建造物も多いのですが、この<U+4E21>建造物の間にある立派な大銀杏が特に素晴らしいです。樹<U+9F62>400年以上を誇る銘木で、天然記念物にも指定されていますので、是非お見逃しなく！文廟は孔子を祀る施設です。ソウルの文廟は元KARAのジヨンが在籍している成均館大<U+5B66>校の構<U+5185>にあります。本殿の大成殿には孔子の位牌があります。周<U+8FBA>の明倫堂や<U+658E>と呼ばれる<U+5F53>時の儒生の寄宿<U+820E>だった建物も必見、中庭の銀杏の木は樹<U+9F62>400年という天然記念物です。最寄りの地下<U+9244><U+99C5>は４<U+53F7>線の「<U+6075>化」、ここから徒<U+6B69>で１０分くらいでした。この場所は大<U+5B66>の敷地にございます。場所は地下<U+9244>４<U+53F7>線<U+6075>化<U+99C5>より徒<U+6B69>で１０分位行ったところにございます。中庭の銀杏は樹<U+9F62>４００年以上もある天然記念物に指定されております。入場料は無料です。

Name: 광화문 광장
Review: Just down from the two large palaces you will find this quite interesting square in the center of the road containing a statue of King Joseon (sitting) and Admiral Yi Sun Shin on a Pedestal.The square also has some interesting potted trees.The Admiral was famous for his battles with the Japanese during their invasion in the 16th Century, at the time Josoen was on the throne.Just 10 years ago, this public square replaced 10 traffic lanes as part of various environmentally friendly renovations going on in Seoul. The big rectangle runs from Gwanghwamun Gate on the North to Sejongno Sageon intersection on the South. We walked its length from the intersection, en route to Gyeongbokgung, the city’s premier palace on a Saturday afternoon. I saw no greenery anywhere on the square to soften the effect of its vast concrete underfoot, but many attention-grabbers beckoned, including two big statues.We encountered the first statue almost immediately, at the Southern edge of the square. It depicts a standing Admiral Yi Sunshin (1545-1598), who led the defeat of the Japanese Navy in the Imijin War. A nearby fountain, known as the 12.23, commemorates the admiral’s 23 battles with 12 warships during that war. The second statue, also nicely crafted, appears in the middle of the square, showing King Sejong (1397-1450) seated on a throne. Among other accomplishments, he created the Korean alphabet.While looking around the king’s statue, we discovered an entrance at the rear that led to a lower level with two free exhibition halls focused on the king and the admiral. History buffs, we spent about 1 hour here, learning fascinating information about both men. Returning to sunlight again, we came across a book fair on the square, where many events are held for the public.Three traffic lanes flank both the East and West sides of the square and a Metro entrance is in the square itself. Government administrative offices appear beyond the lanes on the East Side and the Sejong Center (performing arts), which we also visited, is the standout building on the West side.The square is large with 2 huge statues of Korea's historical figures. And in the background you can see the mountain and the palace.A busy main road with a central area surrounded by a few civic buildings sums up the square. Not much to see except a couple of statues and lots of traffic. Leads up to Gyeongbokgung Palace and gate.Not much to do here other than see the statues. I presume they have events here throughout the year. Seems to be popular with tourists. In a great area as there are lots of coffee shops and restaurants nearby. Good to visit after the palace as it’s just outside.There is a fringe political group holding protests in the area - every weekend apparently - they wear earplugs and shout through very loud speakers, block the way and harangue tourists. I would advise staying away until these folks shuffle off.This is the massive and impressive public square in front of the main entrance to Gwanghwamun Palace and its full of interesting statuary and plenty of plaques explain things that used to be there and things that still do! Great views of the palace and its main gate. Loads of life and bustle about and its very close to the main shoppibg areas and lots of eateries.Great historical figure, lots to learn about the Korean alphabet and their way of thinking based on this historical figureThis square is just in front of Gwanghwamun Gate, the main gate of Gyeongbokgung Palace. The square has 2 imposing statues, ie King Sejong and Admiral Yi Sun-Sin. To know more about the 2 figures, suggest you visit the underground museum, located just behind the statue of the king. Free admission. Nice to spend about 10 to 20 mins enjoying the air con and use the toilet before moving on.This is a very formal and grand public square in honour of the well loved Emperor Sejong.There is a museum in the basement (free admissions) which is below the statute of the Emperor. Look for the interesting displays on the history of Korea, Hangeul language and the lifestyle of the early days.You could watch a short movie, which is very informative, in this small museum.Back to the Gwanghwamun Square, there are many spots for nice photos.

Name: 세종대왕 동상
Review: This is one of two impressive statues in Gwanghaman Square, the other being that of Admiral Yi Sun-Sin. Sejong lived from 1307 until 1450 and was the fourth King in the Jaseon Dynasty.The title of Great" apparently bestowed on all kings after they died but Sejong did invent the Korean alphabet , known as Hangul and promoted science and other good things.And a nice, big and impressive statue it was and fitting for a historic ruler.One of the statues in the square where you can watch the palace and the mountain view behind it. Good for some photos.The Stature of Sejong the Great is usually very busy around Daytime. So make sure you have time. Go in the morning or evening to make some good pictures with the montains behind the stature. Also there are a lot of other great tourists spots around the stature which you may should check out.This imposing statue is the focal point in Gwanghwamun Square. It is to honour King Sejong the Great, the fourth and most respected king of the Joseon Dynasty and creator of Hangeul, Korea's alphabet. A passageway behind the statue leads to a museum, featuring the life and achievements of this king. Free admission.Loved the location on the large square with the mountains in the background. We were delighted to find a door behind the statue which led to a museum about Sejong the Great where we learnt he invented the Korean alphabet!I was here, and I was amazed at the creation of the statue and the history behind it. Come here if you want to enjoy history :).Ever since I've watched a drama about King Sejong, I knew I had to visit his statue and take a photo with him. Little did I know that it's in the center of Seoul. It is very easy to find and impossible to miss when visiting the Gyeongbokgung Palace, Cheonggyecheon Stream, and other famous spots in Seoul.King Sejong's statue is among the popular tourist spots in the area so don't miss taking a souvenir photo with him. You might just have to fall in line. And maybe ask for someone to take your photo if traveling alone like me.so majestically built to one of the best king during joseon dynasty. if I am a Korean, I feel really and totally proud.The statue of King Sejong one of the greatest rulers of Joseon Dynasty has been installed in the G Square as a gratitude for his contribution in strengthening the Joseon Dynasty and also as an inventor of Korean Alphabets <U+2013> the Hangeul, Armillary globe, rain gauge, the Sun dial etc. He is remembered for his contribution to the great strides Korea made in the field of agriculture, science, technology.The bronze statute which is about 9.5 meters high shows the King sitting with a book in his hand and a gentle smile. There are around 6 columns behind the statue showcasing the accomplishments of this great king.There is also an exhibition underground depicting the achievements of the king which is open to public.Include the visit to this place along with the visit G Palace.Located at Gwanghwamun. Good place to visit before/after Gyeongbokgung! The exhibitions were all in Korean though.

Name: 충무공 이순신 동상
Review: Admiral Yi Sun-Yin was a famous Korean Admiral, the inventor of the Turtle Ships and famous for his battles and beating the Japanese during the Imjin Wars. He lived from 1545 until 1598 and died of a gun shot wound in battle.His impressive large statue stands in Gwanghuaman Square and worth a look. Yi Sun-Sin improved on the Turtle Ships that had eleven cannons on each side, two each in the bow and stern and spikes on the roof to avoid being boarded.Some historians have put him alongside Horatio Nelson as a a ship-lover leader but that may be pushing it. Better than Horatio!.Nice Statue but not as nice as the column in London.One of the two statues in this square. The square and statues can be found right infront of the palace. Good for some quick photos.This statue is to honour a famous and respected admiral best known for his military achievements during the Imjin War. There is also a small underground museum in memory of the Admiral. In front of the statue there is a water fountain called 23.12 representing the 23 wars the Admiral won with 12 warships.I saw this when I was walking around Seoul. Very enjoyed reading about the history of Admiral Yi Sun-Sin. Go here if you want to learn about him, and why he is important.Considered as a War hero, the 6.5 meters bronze statue of Admiral Yi Sun-sin is situated in the G Square which is in front of the G-Palace. The statue shows the Admiral in a standing posture, holding a sword in his right hand the face depicting the determination of a soldier.Near the statue there is a miniature turtle ship representing the war vessel which the Admiral supposed to have commanded during the war. There is also a small museum in the memory of the Admiral.Also in front of the statue there is a water fountain called 23.12 representing the 23 wars the Admiral won with 12 warships.I had never heard of this famous 16th-century Korean admiral until I visited Gwanghwamum Plaza, where his bronze statue anchors its southern end. But now I know that Admiral Yi Sun-Sin has a fascinating background, including incredible military achievements during the Imjin War (1592-96) when he defended Korea against Japanese invaders. Yi Sun-Sin invented the ironclad "turtle" ship. It was so successful that it took only a few to win a battle with hundreds of the enemy's traditional ships.Sculptor Kim Se-jung's 1968 work depicts the war hero standing in armor, with a massive sword in the right hand. A miniature replica of the turtle ship appears just below the statue. The bronze and its high pedestal rise about 56 feet above the plaza. The 12:23 fountain nearby received its name from the 23 battles the admiral fought with 12 ships. It was not operating during my day visit in October, but I saw it in action with colored lights, passing by in a bus one night.As a history buff, I enjoyed the small museum under the plaza devoted to Admiral Yi Sun-Sin and King Sejong.This is an impressive statue located in the centre of the city and the great thing about it is that there is a museum underground here where you can also learn so much about Korean history. The statue is very close to the statue of Sejong the Great and also walking distance to Gyeongbokgung Palace.Another great feature here is the water fountain in the evening time. The fountain is lit up and changes colour all the time and here you will always find kids playing in the fountain. My own young kids insisted to come here several times.I just liked the pose of Admiral Yi Sun- Sin as he appears as this bronze statue on Gwanghwamun Square in Seoul. As a hero from the sixteenth century, he is celebrated for his triumphs against the invading Japanese.It is a small statute which you'll automatically pass by when visiting the Gwanghwamun district. There's a year-long protest going on nearby the statute, so make sure you do not offend people there by taking photos like tourists. There's always somekind of protest going on around the statute, which will rarely be a probblem for you, but still, be cautious.It is recommended to start your Seoul trip here along with the statue of King Sejong the Great and then walk to the main palace. There is a nice and free museum under the two statues that tells you about these two great Korean men. The part about Admiral Yi Sun-Sin details great navel battles and shows how he saved Korea from the Japanese invasion overcoming great odds due to strategy and better ship designs. A true David and Goliath story.

Name: 동화 면세점
Location: 서울 종로구 세종로 211 광화문 B/D 지하1층
Review: ツア<U+30FC>で連れて行かれました。ショッピングには何の興味もないので、ぐるっと店<U+5185>を一周してから外に出て、周<U+8FBA>をブラブラしてました。規模が小さく、たいしたことは無いようでした。ロッテや新世界に比べると。やはり見劣りします。今回は終日フリ<U+30FC>で、空港からの送迎のみのツア<U+30FC>で行ったため、ソウルに到着したしてからすぐに、ここに連れてこられましたが、結局何も買いませんでした。到着日かつホテルへのチェックイン前に免<U+7A0E>店に案<U+5185>するＪＴＢのセンスの無さに<U+5446>れました。他に６名いましたが、皆怒っていました。ほしかったeasydew の取り扱いがなかったようで、買うものは特にありませんでした。ツア<U+30FC>に組み<U+8FBC>まれているショッピングなので、時間を潰すのに、近くの小さいコンビニ、ドラッグストアをのぞいてみました。近くにカフェもありました。通りに面しているので、道路やビル、パトカ<U+30FC>を見て、異<U+56FD>を感じながら時間を潰しました。地下<U+9244>の<U+99C5>から遠いところにあるせいか、比較的すいている印象です。中<U+56FD>人の<U+56E3><U+4F53>客に遭遇しなければ、落ち着いて買い物ができます。一通りの韓<U+56FD>や西洋のブランドが一通りそろっており、特にこだわりがなければここで十分かと思います。ロッテや新世界の免<U+7A0E>店は　明洞散策ついでに立ち寄りやすい場所なので　それに比べしまうと東和はショッピングエリアでなく<U+6E05><U+6E13>川や光化門の離れた場所にあるので　若干行きにくいが　とかく高層階にある免<U+7A0E>店店<U+8217>が多くエレベ<U+30FC>タ<U+30FC>がなかなか<U+6765>ないので　行きも<U+5E30>りも待たされ面倒だが　東和はビル地下店<U+8217>でとても入りやすいのでいいです。地下<U+9244>光化門<U+99C5>6番出口からすぐです。コネストのク<U+30FC>ポンを持って地下に行くと、プレゼントが貰えます。3種類から選べるのでBB クリ<U+30FC>ムをいただきました<U+6E05><U+6E13>川沿いを<U+6B69>いて行きました。建物に赤く東和免<U+7A0E>店とあるので、<U+6B69>いている時いい目印になりました。JCBカ<U+30FC>ドと優待ガイドを案<U+5185>デスクに見せ、入店プレゼントをもらってきました。<U+6B74>史が古く、親切な免<U+7A0E>店。こじんまりして、スタッフもアットホ<U+30FC>ムで、何よりゆっくり見ることができます。大きな免<U+7A0E>店よりは品<U+6570>は少なくみえますが、<U+53B3>選された感じを受けます。ソウルで昔からある免<U+7A0E>店ですが工事中、TCが使えないと言ったり支離滅裂ほとんど買わないで<U+5E30>りました空港から送迎付きのツア<U+30FC>だと大<U+4F53>ココに寄ります。地下一階から地上までブランド品が<U+6CA2>山入ってます。男性にはあまり興味無いかも知れません。免<U+7A0E>店はこことロッテ、しんらが有名ですね。

Name: 세종 문화 회관
Review: 光化門にあるソウル最大の<U+56FD>立劇場。今回で３作品目の<U+89B3>劇となりましたが、<U+56FD>立だけあって建物は重厚感あり、ソウルの中では好きな劇場の一つです。劇場は３階までありますが、<U+6A2A>に<U+5E83>い造りでキャパ3000を越えます。劇場の前には世宗大王像、その後ろには光化門、そして大統領官邸の<U+9752>瓦台も見えます。好きなア<U+30FC>ティストが主役を務めたミュ<U+30FC>ジカルを見に行きました。明洞から頑張れば<U+6B69>けますが地下<U+9244>でも行けますし、私は表玄<U+95A2>のすぐ前に到着して便利なバスで行きました。melonのオンラインサイトでチケットを購入しましたが、<U+5F53>日はスム<U+30FC>ズにチケットに引き換えができました。<U+4F1A>場自<U+4F53>はコンパクトで綺麗です。座り心地も良かったです。ロビ<U+30FC>にはカフェもあります。ジョン<U+30FB>キャメロン<U+30FB>ミッチェル<U+6765>韓公演で行きました。チケットを取る前に調べたところ<U+6A2A>に<U+5E83>いというのを知ったのですが本<U+5F53>でした。A～Eブロックに分かれていましたが、普通の劇場ならB～Dぐらいまでの<U+6A2A>幅じゃないでしょうか？また、最前列に座ったのですが、ステ<U+30FC>ジまでが遠かったです。各席にモニタ<U+30FC>があり、字幕が出ました。最前列の場合はステ<U+30FC>ジにモニタ<U+30FC>があって、字幕が遠かったです。世宗文化<U+4F1A>館の<U+4F1A>員制度が2種類あります。（年<U+4F1A>費が違います）それによってチケット優先予約があったり、チケットが30％引き、劇場<U+5185>のカフェの無料券がもらえたりします。<U+99C5>直結ですし、設備も新しくキレイな劇場です。ちなみに出待ちは世宗王の像がある正面側ではなく、建物の裏側になります。11月21日にコンサ<U+30FC>トのために訪れました。光化門<U+5E83>場に位置するソウルでも<U+4F1D>統と格式のある劇場で、大劇場は3階席まであって3,000人以上を<U+53CE>容できるようです。外<U+89B3>の威容と同<U+69D8>、<U+5185>部もクラシカルで重厚な雰<U+56F2><U+6C17>が漂い、ソウルを代表するに相<U+5FDC>しいホ<U+30FC>ルだと思いました。<U+5E83>大な空間の大劇場は、シ<U+30FC>トも余裕のある配置で快適に2時間半以上のコンサ<U+30FC>トを<U+697D>しむことができました。道を隔てて世宗大王像があり、その下が世宗大王像記念館になっています。大王像側からの入り口は<U+72ED>いのですが、記念館はなかなかの<U+5E83>さ。出る時は道の向こう側にあった世宗文化<U+4F1A>館でした。地下で<U+7E4B>がっていた事にビックリ。コンサ<U+30FC>トホ<U+30FC>ルや美術館が入っている立派な建物です。ポ<U+30FC>ルポッツさんの10周年コンサ<U+30FC>トに行ってきました。二千人入るホ<U+30FC>ルだそうで、色んな方がゲストで出演されていました。<U+6B74>史のあるホ<U+30FC>ルだと聞きましたが、座席によく飛行機についてあるような、モニタ<U+30FC><U+753B>面も付いていて古さはそこまで感じませんでした。化粧室は流石に<U+8FBC>んでいる時は<U+6E05>掃が行き<U+5C4A>いて無いようでしたが、最初の方はきれいだったので、中間ででも<U+6E05>掃に<U+6C17>を付けて貰えれば良いかなと思いました。前から<U+6C17>になっていた世宗大王像の裏側の入口へ入ってみました。夜7時過ぎでしたが、夏休み中の子ども達の<U+697D>しそうな<U+58F0>がします。入場無料で世宗と李舜臣の偉業が<U+5B66>べます。<U+4F53><U+9A13>型も多くて予備知識の無かった高校生の娘でも、<U+697D>しめたようです。見<U+5B66>後に同じフロアにある<U+98F2>食店を利用しました。8時頃の夕食も安心して過ごせる店が<U+4E26>んでいます。旅行中、子ども連れの方が夜も<U+697D>しめる穴場かも知れません。光化門<U+5E83>場の地下にある施設で、入場は無料です。世宗王に<U+95A2>する<U+6B74>史や展示が充<U+5B9F>しており、無料にしては充<U+5B9F>していると思います。少し<U+6B8B>念なのは英語または日本語での<U+8AAC>明が少なくあまり理解できなかったことですが、<U+4E80>甲船の展示や映像での<U+8AAC>明もあるので、<U+697D>しめる場所だとは思います。ミュ<U+30FC>ジカルを<U+89B3>に訪れました。外<U+89B3>のあまりの大きさにビックリしてしまいましたが、ホ<U+30FC>ルだけでなく複合施設になっていました。お手洗いも綺麗で安心。舞台はもちろん素晴らしく、座席がゆったりと座りやすく、音響も良かったです。ミュ<U+30FC>ジカルの世界にどっぷりと浸れる優雅な時間を過ごせました。地下<U+9244>の<U+99C5>から近いのですが、大雨の中すぐにたどり着けませんでした。劇場は<U+6A2A>に長くミュ<U+30FC>ジカルにはむいていないかなと心配でしたが、はじまったらそんなことは忘れてしまいました。音響も良く、座席は<U+5E83>いです。トイレはとてもきれいでした。開演15分前からしか座席につけませんでした。

Name: 씨네큐브 광화문
Rank: 55위(285곳의 서울 소재 즐길 거리 / 게임 중)
Review: CGV is Megabox, two giant movie theatre chains in Korea, have overtaken cinema industry in Korea. These multiplexes each have 10+ theatres in one location and yet, most of them are full of blockbusters. Many art movies or Oscar contending movies, are usually not available in those places. Cinecube is one of a few independent theatres in Seoul where they screen those good in-the-monority type of movies. There are only two screens here, and obviously seats numbers are very small and limited, but that only makes the whole experience much better. If you are getting sick of what the multiplexes are throwing at you, and you're wanting to see those real good movies, not only in english but also in french, spanish and whatnot, check out this place. One of the good thing about this place is you can almost always get a ticket on sight without making a reservation beforehand. Enjoy!

Name: 서울대학교병원 의학박물관
Review: ソウル大<U+5B66><U+533B><U+5B66>部付<U+5C5E>病院にあり、<U+72EC>特の雰<U+56F2><U+6C17>でした。本館の２階が展示室で、古い器具は素人には理解しにくい<U+5185>容でした。<U+6B74>史は感じます。漢<U+533B><U+5B66>の博物館は何度か見<U+5B66>していますが、韓<U+56FD>の西洋<U+533B><U+5B66>博物館は初めてでした。腎不全、心疾患などわかりやすく展示されています。特に印象に<U+6B8B>ったのは病前<U+30FB>病中の患者さんの顔の<U+7D75>。 見過ごせない<U+69D8>子が形として目の前に示されたのが衝<U+6483>的でした。しばらく見入ってしまいました。こういう展示は見たことがなく、改めて患者さんサイドの心情や感情に<U+6C17>付かされました。展示物の<U+8AAC>明に日本語表記があれば、さらに<U+697D>しめると感じましたが、建物の見<U+5B66>といった側面でも行く<U+4FA1>値は十分にあります。建物前の噴水は、作動していませんでしたが季節的なもので止まっているだけかもしれませんが、作動していれば正面から見る建物のグレ<U+30FC>ドをアップしてくれることでしょう。地下<U+9244>4<U+53F7>線<U+6075>化(Hyahwa)の近くのソウル大<U+5B66>病院の敷地のなかにある博物館です。レンガ造りの建物は日本が統治する前の大韓帝<U+56FD>時代の1908年に建てられました。韓<U+56FD>初期の西洋建築で西洋<U+533B><U+5B66>の病院です。この建物の2階が無料の博物館です。事務所にも使用しているので、入口のガ<U+30FC>ドマンに博物館見<U+5B66>の旨を告げて入ります。西洋<U+533B><U+5B66>を導入した初期のころからの<U+6B74>史の展示やいろいろな<U+533B>療機械の展示がありました。私は<U+533B>療分野の知識がないうえ、<U+8AAC>明パネルはハングルのみなので古い漢文の資料以外、ちょっとなんだかよく分からないものもありました。<U+533B>療探訪FAMツア<U+30FC>で行きました。まず、建物自<U+4F53>が<U+6B74>史があって、とてもいいです!1900年代初頭に建てられたようですが、ミュ<U+30FC>ジアムとしてでなく、いくつか事務室もありました。韓<U+56FD>西洋<U+533B><U+5B66>のメッカである、ソウル大<U+5B66>の施設だけあって、展示はなかなか充<U+5B9F>しています。日本にはなかなかこのような施設はないので、とても興味深かったです。また、この建物には京大のような大時計もあるのですが、<U+5185>部からその仕組みを見<U+5B66>することができます。ミニチュアモデルもあって、自分で<U+5B9F>際に動かすこともできます。

Name: 이화 벽화마을
Review:
There weren't so many murals but the neighborhood itself was delightful and sweet to explore. If you have an hour to spend, this would be a great place to go.My husband and I decided to head out to Ihwa Mural Village early Saturday morning. We followed the directions found...더 보기I stumbled upon this village almost by mistake after hiking along the Seoul Wall. It’s a great walk up and you can include a visit to the Wall Museum, which is interesting and entrance is free. The village itself is just a good place to...더 보기Some of the locals were fed up with the visitors so they painted over the more famous murals, Some of them are very childish and obviously painted by amateurs.It's nice to walk around! Be prepared to face some big stairs though.
Also, it's not that big so you'll be finished in no timeWe stumbled across this village as we were walking to our next destination and saw some really beautiful wall art. A really lovely little stumble, even in the rain!There are a series of hills to get to the village from the information center and then a series of steep stairs throughout the mural route that would make it difficult for families with small children to complete the tour. We ended up staying on...더 보기While searching the web for places to explore in Seoul, I chanced upon this interesting village and decided to make a trip here. As expected, there are many murals of colourful designs spread over the village or rather a town. There are signs recommending a...더 보기This was a super unique experience in Seoul! I loved the opportunity to wander aimlessly, and discover lots of interesting shops and views! The street art is fun and offers great opportunities for social media posts. <U+0001F602>Loving the trip up to this quaint little village. One of the highlights of our 9D8N trip. Interesting shops around for browsing around. Hubby even bought 2*shirts for KRW10,000! Highly recommended if you want a day out of Seoul city.

Name: 수성동 계곡
Review:
玄人好みの西村の先に位置する、不思議な<U+6E13>谷でした。岩の浸食具合が絶妙で、滑らかな表面が何とも言えない印象を<U+6B8B>しました。地下<U+9244><U+99C5>から20分くらい<U+6B69>きますが、バスでも行けます。
私が行ったときは天<U+6C17>が<U+60AA>かったせいか、人が少なかったですが、天<U+6C17>...더 보기西村のゲストハウスに泊まった際にオ<U+30FC>ナ<U+30FC>のおじさんが<U+6559>えてくれました。徒<U+6B69>5分のところに<U+6E13>谷があると。
朝5時半に起きて...더 보기

Name: 종묘
Review: 今回４度目の宗廟見<U+5B66>でしたが、ちょうど日本語ツア<U+30FC>の時間ではないため、英語のツア<U+30FC>に<U+53C2>加しました。ここの<U+6982>要が分かっていれば、特に、英語が良く理解できなくても、ツア<U+30FC>の皆さんに同行しながら、自由に見<U+5B66>できます。朝鮮王朝<U+6B74>代の王と王妃、および<U+6CA1>後に位を贈られた王と王妃の位牌が安置されている、王室の<U+970A>廟です。正殿<U+30FB>永寧殿は、<U+56FD>王らが亡くなるたびに位牌を安置する空間を一室、一室<U+5897>築してきたため、東西１００m以上に伸びる珍しい建物で、<U+5358>一建築としては世界最大だそうです。キョンボックンに比べて華やかさはないですが、人も少なく、<U+7DD1>が多いです。野生のリスも住み着いていて、癒されました。無料の日本語ツア<U+30FC>あります。ソウル地下<U+9244>（メトロ）3<U+53F7>線<U+30FB>5<U+53F7>線鐘路三街（チョンノサムガ）<U+99C5>から徒<U+6B69>5分の場所にあり、通常入場料は1,000Wだが8/10~8/25の夏休み期間中は無料だった。朝鮮王朝時代の<U+6B74>代の<U+56FD>王たちをまつる祭壇で、日本での神社に相<U+5F53>する神聖な場所で世界遺産にも登<U+9332>されている。また、もうひとつの世界遺産である昌<U+5FB3>宮（チャンドックン）からは<U+6B69>いて15分程度である。原則入場時はガイドツア<U+30FC>が必須であり、日本語ガイドツア<U+30FC>はほぼ1時間ごとに<U+5B9F>施されている。ただし<U+6BCE>週火曜は定休日で、また土曜はガイドツア<U+30FC>が<U+5B9F>施されず自由見<U+5B66>となる。以前訪れたときはガイドツア<U+30FC>に<U+53C2>加し所要時間は約50分、今回は土曜に訪れたので自由見<U+5B66>で40分ほどかけて敷地<U+5185>を散策した。所要時間1時間の日本語のガイドツア<U+30FC>に<U+53C2>加しました。自由散策では知ることのできない<U+6B74>史や見どころを<U+6559>えてくださるので、予定が合えば是非ガイドツア<U+30FC>に<U+53C2>加してほしいです。比較的ゆっくりと回ってくださるので、<U+5199><U+771F>もたっぷり撮れますし、何より<U+7DD1>が多くて自然豊かですごく癒されました。日本語中<U+56FD>語英語などなど<U+69D8><U+3005>な言語を話せるガイドさんがいらっしゃってとても勉<U+5F37>になります。8月はまだ暑いので<U+98F2>み物を持っていくべきです。ここも入場料は安い。森の中に道があり、<U+771F>ん中は魂の通り道とあるので、慌てて、<U+6A2A>に避ける。建物を外から見るのがメインで、中は殆ど見られないが(控えの間などを除き)、韓流ドラマが好きで、朝鮮王に馴染みがあれば、<U+6765>られてとても嬉しい場所。とっても<U+9759>かで美しい場所でした。土曜日以外はガイド見<U+5B66>（１時間くらい）になりますが、<U+8AAC>明を聞きながらの散策良かったです。もし私が自由見<U+5B66>したならなんとな～く散<U+6B69>して「あぁ綺麗だったね」で終わるところでした。日本語ガイドは９時、９時４０分<U+30FB><U+30FB><U+30FB>とスタ<U+30FC>ト時間が決まっています。入場料は\1000。安いです。園<U+5185>は自然豊かで木の上がガサガサっとしたと思ったらリスがいました。土曜日に行きました。　人が少なく、とても<U+9759>かな<U+89B3>光ができました。　園<U+5185>の木<U+3005>、建物とても落ち着いていて良い感じです。建物は本<U+5F53>に素晴らしい。　園<U+5185>を<U+6B69>いて一周できます。　ちょっとした散<U+6B69>コ<U+30FC>スになっていて良いです。平日は外<U+56FD>人向けの案<U+5185>が居るみたいです。<U+6BCE>年５月の第１日曜日に開催される宗廟大祭を見<U+5B66>しました。<U+5F53>日は、無料で入場できますが、<U+4F1A>場に入るには行列必至です。１１時頃に着きましたが、すごい行列だったので、先に<U+663C>食を<U+6442>って、お<U+663C>から再度<U+4E26>んで入場しました。所作が行われている<U+5E83>場を周りの椅子に座って見ることになります。<U+5E83>場の外には大型<U+753B>面に映し出されるビュ<U+30FC>イング席も用意されていました。<U+6B74>史を感じることができるお祭りです。

Name: 동대문 (흥인지문)
Review: Amazing building, really worth the visit and spending some time to soak it all in!Super easy to access via the subway system and conveniently located, this is a must visit!This is one of 8 gates. You could not enter when I was there, only a photo from outside.Its name means great east gate.You can access it from either subway 1 or 4.Walk past Dongdaeumun Design Centre, and keep walking straight - the Heunginjimun Gate will suddenly appear in view. It's an impressive structure - a two tiered building on a solid stone base in which there is a tunnel which housed the gate. This is the East Gate of Seoul, one of four main gates in the old Seoul City Wall. The Gate was first built by King Taejo during his fifth year of reign (1398). It was renovated in 1453, and the current structure is the one rebuilt in 1869.What is particularly impressive is the half circle outer wall enclosure (the Ongseong). This was a powerful defensive device because visitors who entered were surrounded. It also protects the gate against a battering ram.You can view it from all around, but there is no entry.To best view it, you need to cross the road up to the Heunginjimun Gate Park which is where the City Wall now starts, and view it on eye level.Information about the gate is sparse, even though the small information placard states it is Korea's National Treasure number 1. To find out more and to see the Jaspyan statues up close, visit the Seoul City Wall Museum which is about 100 metres up in the Heunginjimun Gate Park. It's free to visit, has scale models and a lot of fascinating information about the gate and the Seoul City Wall.See my photos.I came across this massive gate, one of the four major entrances to Seoul centuries ago, while walking to the nearby Dongdaemun Design Center. An imposing structure, this is the only city gate with a small wall that was constructed to give the Joseon Dynasty fortress additional protection against invaders. Though originally built in 1398, the gate has undergone many restorations, and it appeared to me that one must have occurred quite recently, based on its current excellent condition.Located in an extremely busy traffic area, this Eastern gate can be difficult to reach on foot. Though I managed to do so, the entrance was blocked off and the effort to get there hardly seemed worthwhile. I ended up ascending a small hill across the street by the Seoul City Wall. This provided a superb vantage point for the gate and the surrounding neighborhood. My visit occurred during the afternoon. Later, when I walked by at night, the gate had been beautifully illuminated and I had an even better appreciation of the structure. Dongdaemun Gate is about a 5-minute walk from the Dongdaemun Subway stop (Lines 1 and 4). Take Exit 1 or 6 - 10.One thing I hate about Seoul is how bloody difficult it can be to cross the street. You can't really get close to the gate because of how the gates are set up, so don't feel bad if none of your pics turn out right. After some shopping at the nearby namdaemun market, you can come here for some shots. There's several of these bad boys around Seoul, so go catch em all.Interesting gate, but not as accessible or explained as well as the Sungnyemun Gate. Good for some photos and as a point to start a longer walk to explore the Seoul City Wall, which commences just North of the Dongdaemun Gate and climbs up to Naksan Park.Also known as Heunginjimun Gate, it is the largest gate in Seoul. A unique feature is the half-circle shaped wall to protect the gate. In fact, it is the only gate among Seoul’s eight gates to have this wall. For a good photo shoot, suggest you cross the road and climb uphill for about 5 to 10 mins in Dongdaemun Seonggwak Park. I visited during the late afternoon. I suppose evening is a better time to appreciate the buildings with the lighting.Though reconstructed several times throughout its 700 year history it is a magnificent monument to the Joseon Dynasty. Though inspiring from street level, it is even more impressive from the lounge or roomss facing from the JW Marriott Dongdaemun Square.Looking at the pictures, I should have gone at night. But even during the day the gate looks very impressive.Heunginjimun, literally "Gate of Rising Benevolence" or Dongdaemun, is one of The Eight Gates of Seoul in the Fortress Wall of Seoul, a prominent landmark in central Seoul. The Korean name "Dongdaemun" means "Great East Gate," and it was so named because it was the major eastern gate in the wall that surrounded Seoul during the Joseon Dynasty. The structure was first built by King Taejo during his fifth year of reign (1398). It was renovated in 1453, and the current structure is the one rebuilt in 1869.

Name: 종로3가 포장마차거리
Review: This is a food stall & pub street in Jongno-3-ga. People have got together here to get cheap foods & drinks since a long ago. Feel the amazing atmosphere of average people.- The location is near Jongno-3-ga Station Line #5(purple).- For foreign tourists, they have to embrace some hygiene problem. It's not clean enough mostly. A language, too. They are not foreigner friendly.- Instead, they are affordable and good for the price.

Name: 교보문고 광화문
Review: Kyobo is a chain, so there are stores all over Seoul, but the Gwanghwamun location is my favorite. They sell books and CDs, which reminds me of what the States used to have in the Borders chains, along with even more stuff. There are cafes and restaurants inside, too. There are sections for foreign languages and, depending on your language, there are likely specialty shops elsewhere that will better serve you. The English section is small, but has great editions, like Oxfords World’s Classics, at cheap prices. The literary selection tends to be canonical, but the staff also has a large section devoted to best-sellers and newly published material, most of which is non-fiction, that is a sort of Korean-American cultural filter. There are always lots of families here and people milling about, reading, gathering books, enmeshed in the written word and the real world. Take some time here, slow down, observe, read something, think a few connected thoughts, have something to eat or drink...and enjoy. Over the past five or six years, there has been lots of renovation in the areas adjacent, particularly with high end restaurants and shops behind Kyobo and to the left. Jongno has remained the same and the Gwanghwamun Gwangjang is historical. Several years ago the Korean people protested then President Park Geun-Hye with candlelight vigils and songs on the square, every Saturday, for months. These protests began with small numbers that grew into the thousands, and arguably millions. These protests were part of the success in the removal of Park (December, 2016) and were amazing representations of the civil, non-violent assemblage of people for a cause. Democracies around the world would do well to follow in these Korean footsteps.This is a huge bookstore, connected to the Gwanghwamun metro station. A must visit for those who likes books, although mostly Korean books. There is also an English section. Do check out their interesting stationery items as well.Kyobo bookstore in Jongno-gu (near Gwanghwamun station) is a must-visit for anyone with a passion for books and simply spending time in bookstores. This particular branch (there are others dotted around the city) is, I believe, the largest. It has a vast collection of books in Korean, and sections for a number of other languages, with quite a good selection of books in English. The store also has a stationery section, puzzles and a cafe, and is surrounded by a number of other shops. Unlike so many bookstores these days, Kyobo allows you to spend time simply sitting on the provided comfortable benches, and reading. You'll find the store in the basement, accessible from the station.Without doubt the biggest book store I’ve ever seen, including Barnes & Nobel in the USA.Small English section, but were in Korea.Truly amazing to see how the experience is developed, the cafes, the associated offerings, eg Mont Blanc store. Retail at its bestThis is a big bookstore with many sections. We spent well over an hour in the stationery section alone. Super cute gift items. It's great to see so many people sitting in chairs or standing reading books. This place is a must visit for book lovers, even if you can't read Korean.Probably biggest book store what I've seen. Not only books but parfumes, DVD and CD, electronics, coffee shop etc. Basically you can spent whole day in this book store without get bored. Also goid selection of English language books available.There is a huge variety of books here, in fact same as similar shops everywhere in the world. Possible to find books in English, one good plus. For stationary materials, it is better and cheaper to enter smaller shops specific for stationary. You will lose much less time. Same is valid for other goods such as souvenirs, wallets, bags, toys, etc. If you want to buy only book and have specific list, enter and buy. Otherwise you can become crazy in crowd. As a summary, other than huge variety of books, nothing special.This Book Store is amazing! It's located at the Basement of the Kyobo Building. The person at the Information Counter was so helpful and efficient. She gave me a print out based on the info which I gave her (Book Titles & ISBN Numbers) in order for me to locate the books that I was looking for. As I was pressed for time, I went to the designated location but was too overwhelmed andI decided to ask their Book Concierge Counter for assistance. The lady was so helpful and found the books which I was looking for very quickly. If you love books, this is a must place to visit! I will definitely go again and spend at least a day in this Book Store!I stumbled on this while walking out of the Gwanghwamun subway station and was amazed at the range of books and local crowd on a Sunday morning. The English section is located on a corner closer to the cafe. It is one of the largest I have seen in Seoul as English books are not common. Especially for literature on Korean art and culture published by the national cultural institute. There is also a comprehensive list of titles published by Tuttle books on Korean national identity and history. There are also titles on the Korean War as well as current works on North Korea. The store also has a nice cafe and sections devoted to stationery and fine writing instruments. I wish there would be more such stores in Singapore as this reflects the knowledge seeking identity of a nation and I am happy that print is still king in some places.We were recommended to visit the bookstore and music store by the Tourist Information Center (I would recommend you to ask them for advice - superb service). We were looking for some KPop albums as well as some specific stationery. Kyoto bookstore (with HotTracks music store inside) are located at the basement and once you get there, you will be amazed. Through costs is relatively more expensive than Malaysia for the same items, there are just a wide variety of things not seen else where - books, Stationeries, music albums.

Name: 종로 귀금속 거리
Review:
Shopping for jade in the Jongno district is ok but I couldn’t find much jade stores but heaps of jewellery. Make sure you have good bargaining skills as some of the merchants can be tough.
Can’t wait to be back there in December.There is approximately 4-5 kilometres of street grouping with sales centre of jewellery, gold, and pearl, which comes in thousands...더 보기Kisha is a great shop for custom jewelry, and also has good selection of gold, diamonds and pearl items.   Very nice service and helpful.  Great experience and value.

Name: 서울 대학로
Review: 意味不明の名前でしたが、かつてソウル大<U+5B66>のキャンパスがあった一大文<U+6559>エリアだったとのこと。確かに、今も<U+533B><U+5B66>部のキャンパスは<U+6B8B>っています。前衛的な演劇や安い<U+98F2>食店＆宿など、若者のえ年るギ<U+30FC>を感じる街です。モニュメントも素敵です。地下<U+9244><U+6075>化<U+99C5>から徒<U+6B69>10分以<U+5185>のところに、たくさんの演劇ホ<U+30FC>ルや舞台小屋があります。<U+6BCE>日大小の演劇やミュ<U+30FC>ジカルが上演されていています。<U+5F53>日券も買えるので、手<U+8EFD>に生舞台が<U+697D>しめます。シンプルなスト<U+30FC>リ<U+30FC>が多いので、言葉もわからなくても面白いです。ミュ<U+30FC>ジカルの方がより入りやすいと思います。以前から<U+6075>化<U+99C5>の周<U+8FBA>には若者が多く<U+5B66>生たちの街みたいな感じがします。まあ比較的に安く食べられる所も有るし格安旅行者には利用しやすい場所ですね。地下<U+9244><U+6075>花の<U+99C5>を降りるとすぐそこに立派なホ<U+30FC>ル。街の中へ<U+6B69>いて行くとそこここに劇場があり、夕方行くと開演か<U+5F53>日券待ちの人の列も見られます。<U+5B66>生の多い繁華街で庶民的な食堂も多く、その多くが日本語メニュ<U+30FC>も<U+63B2>げているので、食事は市<U+5185>中心部で芝居の終演後にする（店探しに結構苦<U+52B4>）よりこちらでしておいた方がよかったか、と後で思いました。若者文化を感じられて、元<U+6C17>になれる街の一つです。たくさんの<U+98F2>食店や洋服屋さんがあり若者の街といった感じ。このエリアにはよく朝ごはんを食べに<U+6765>ます。日本人には馴染みのない「スンデ」。そのスンデがとっても美味しいレストランが<U+6075>化にあるのです。スンデクッパ、渦<U+5DFB>き<U+72B6>の<U+713C>きスンデは絶品。やっぱり韓<U+56FD>はス<U+30FC>プが最高！<U+5965>深いです。「スンデ<U+5B9F><U+9332>」というレストランはイチオシ。キレイで<U+5E83>いし韓<U+56FD>らしい食事を<U+697D>しめます。劇場の街で、中小さまざまな劇場が存在してます。カフェや<U+98F2>食店も多く1日居ても飽きない場所です。<U+6075>化<U+99C5>の近くには露天が出てるので、手<U+8EFD>に<U+8EFD>食も味わえます。公演は夕方や夜公演がメインですが、小劇場の中には<U+663C>間の公演も多く、<U+5F53>日券でも<U+89B3>ることができる公演も多く、今回は<U+5F53>日にチケットセンタ<U+30FC>で割引でチケット購入し、お得に<U+89B3>ることができました。次回もまた必ず行きたいと思います。演劇を行ってる劇場がたくさんあり大<U+5B66>路<U+99C5>のすぐ近くに<U+5C02>用のインフォメ<U+30FC>ションセンタ<U+30FC>があり公演情報を得ることができます。ただし外<U+56FD>人<U+89B3>光客向けの公演をやっているところはまだまだ少ないです。大<U+5B66>路の中でも少し南側にある弘益大大<U+5B66>路ア<U+30FC>トセンタ<U+30FC>へ行ってきました。大<U+5B66>路の最寄り<U+99C5>は<U+6075>化<U+99C5>ですが、そこからだと少し<U+6B69>かなければなりません。バスだとバス停が近くにあるので<U+6B69>かなくてすみます。ア<U+30FC>トセンタ<U+30FC>は大きくてすぐにわかりました。<U+4F1A>場もきれいでした。地下<U+9244>の<U+6075>化<U+99C5>周<U+8FBA>に<U+5E83>がる、劇場などが多い街です。若い人が<U+6CA2>山いて活<U+6C17>があり、<U+6B69>いていると近隣の劇場の公演の呼び<U+8FBC>みなどを目にすることが出<U+6765>ます。<U+5965>へ<U+5965>へと路地が<U+7D9A>いており、坂の上には有名な壁<U+753B>ア<U+30FC>トの街<U+4E26>みが<U+5E83>がっています。以前のソウル大<U+5B66>のお膝元、<U+6B69>道のオブジェや点在する劇場がお<U+6D12>落です。冬ソナのロケ地にもなったし、上り坂はキツイですが駱山公園や路上美術館は映<U+753B>やドラマのロケ地の<U+5B9D>庫で足を延ばす<U+4FA1>値あり。私は路地裏のマッコリバ<U+30FC>の「ドゥドゥ」がお<U+6C17>に入りです～

Name: 국립 고궁 박물관
Review: This museum is in the grounds of Gyeonbokgung palace and is a great place to get a bit more understanding about the Joseon dynasties - especially if you didn't have guided tour of the palace. Just the right size to be interesting but not bombard you with too much information.Entrance is free and there is audio guide that you can rent at the information desk. It is located within Gyeongbukgung but just outside the ticketing booth. Plenty of displays and descriptions depicting the lives of the royal families who lived in the palaces. Took us an hour to complete though we would love to stay longer.I arrived at the Gyeongbokgung Palace at 0930hr, too early to witness the changing of royal guards ceremony at 1000hr, Hence I decided to visit this nearby museum first. There are free digital locker to store my backpack. This museum displays royal relics from the Joseon Dynasty. There are many exhibition halls, with each hall displaying exhibits of Kings of the Joseon Dynasty, Joseon Palaces, Royal Court Life, Korean Empire, Astronomy & Science Hall Ⅰ, Royal Court Paintings, Jongmyo, the Royal Ancestral Shrine, Royal Court Music, Royal Procession, Astronomy & Science Hall Ⅱ. After visiting the museum, I have a better understanding of the King’s life during that era. Admission is free with toilet facilities and seats for resting.This museum covering several dynasties of Korea is well worth a visit, and well take you 2-3 hours. Beautiful displays of wonderful historical objects. There is a small restaurant on site to take time to relax.Entrance to the museum is free and audio guides of various languages can be obtained at the information desks at 1k KRW. The audio guide is user friendly which detects exhibits automatically so you dont have to key in anything. The museum is well kept and organised and gives good explanation to the Josean dynasty. Worth going if you are heading to Gyeongbukgung grounds.This was a free museum located off the main parade grounds of Gyeongbokgung Palace. We toured the Palace and grounds first, watched the changing of the guards ceremony before heading indoors to tour this museum. Inside there were three floors of history that covered practically all aspects of royal life, from birth until death, for the Joseon dynasty. The following stood out for us:-The display on royal processions was quite impressive as it explained the size and significance of the various groups of people who were required to escort the king during a formal outing. -The scientific accomplishments and capabilties including a water clock but unfortunately for us was going through maintenance during our visit. I thought the displays and their explanations was very well put together and held the interest of the whole family. Compared to the crowds attending the changing of the guards ceremony it felt like we had the museum to ourself.The museum is medium sized compared to most museums I've visited, but that means it is extensive enough to peak your interest but manageable enough to complete in one morning/afternoon session. The exhibits range all the way back to the 1300s until 1910 when the Korean royalty was overthrown by the Japanese.I felt walking through here that a lot was expected from crown prince from birth that from the age of 5 it was constant preparation to lead a country and to be a great king. Not that it was easier on crown princess.It makes you reflect on the weight of a kingdom.The palace museum shows a large collection and explanations of different king dynasties and different royal belongings during the last centuries.Museum currently has an exhibit of things from Lichtenstein. While cool, it takes up most of the museum which leaves not a lot of information on Korean palaces. Overall, museum does a good job explaining what you are seeing and setting you up for Gyeongbokgung which is next door.

Name: 동대문 시장
Review: So much choice.. easy going.. good food.. made fresh.. browse through the market before you decide what and where you want to eat.. you might want to try it all and won't have space for allInteresting place with nice local food. Very close proximity to the train station (Exit 9 of Hongik Univ Station) so its very very easily accessible. A must go if you are a first timer in Korea!So kind of products you can find toys,bag,clothes with good price. But sales person do not know english. Therefore it is so hard to discuss. they are showing price with calculate machine it is realy problem.I went to this market and tried all kinds of street food available in Seoul..the soju was cheap and the food excellent.Could not finish so many choices so need to come back again in futureGreat variety of shops and stalls. There are all types clothes and goods for sale and plenty of food on offerLots of stores and street food options. Many western style malls but each mall offers essentially the same range of stores such as Adidas etc. Contrastingly local malls are full of toot and not particularly useful for foreigners.Stall after stall selling what is seemingly the same food. I found places that looked the freshest and tried a lot of different dishes. I have no idea what I ate, but it was all good!There are many restaurants and also shops selling clothings, shoes, bags. Nothing exciting. Not highly recommended. Visit only if you have time.This is not one market, but is a large commercial district comprising of shopping malls such as Doota, Migliore, apM Place and traditional markets such as wholesale clothing, shoes etc. The iconic landmark is the Heunginjimun Gate. It is best to visit in the evening when it is lively, though crowded. Suggest you climb uphill for 5 to 10 mins just behind the Heunginjimun Gate, to have a great view of the surrounding area.Many small shops and restaurants nearby. Mostly young crowd. Evening is better to walk around. Easy to get to by subway

Name: 롯데백화점 본점
Review:
正直あまり安くありません。もし安く買いたいなら免<U+7A0E>店ではありませんが明洞のス<U+30FC>パ<U+30FC>マ<U+30FC>ケットで買うべきです。免<U+7A0E>店は9:30から空いているので、雨で<U+89B3>光できない朝、買い物へ。免<U+7A0E>店の入り口にスタ<U+30FC>の手形があって、手をはめると、<U+753B>...더 보기食品<U+58F2>り場の韓<U+56FD>海苔をいつも購入しています。高級感がありお土産に最適。安い海苔とは一味違うような<U+6C17>がします。フ<U+30FC>ドコ<U+30FC>トを家族が利用しました！

デパ<U+30FC>トには免<U+7A0E>店もあるし、トイレも便利だしとて...더 보기韓<U+56FD>旅行では、地下<U+58F2>り場の韓<U+56FD>海苔の<U+713C>き海苔を5袋セットを必ず買っていきます。以前は1袋3,000Wと5袋で1パック15...더 보기世界的ブランドから韓<U+56FD>ブランドまで<U+63C3>っていて、立地も良いし、<U+5E83>すぎず廻るのにちょうど良いデパ<U+30FC>トで<U+6C17>に入っています。ロッテ百貨店でエゴマ油を購入しTAX FREE をしました。パスポ<U+30FC>ト、還付レシ<U+30FC>ト、購入した品物を持って空港で<U+7A0E><U+95A2>申告...더 보기地下１階の食品フロアにある、リカ<U+30FC>ショップでいつもマッコリを購入して<U+5E30>るのですが、今回はフ<U+30FC>ドコ<U+30FC>トで<U+98F2>むことにしました...더 보기韓<U+56FD>に行くたびにお邪魔させて頂いています。兎に角、必要なものは何でもあるので便利です。ブランド品からス<U+30FC>パ<U+30FC>にはキムチ<U+58F2>...더 보기店員さんが日本語で<U+5BFE><U+5FDC>してくれて、親切に<U+8AAC>明をしてくれたので、とても良い買い物が出<U+6765>ました。
